s.text: One judge waited more than three years for confirmation.
The president--and this has been especially true of Clinton--frequently nominates the least offensive nominee rather than the most qualified in order to pacify the Senate.
Helms, for example, held up numerous ambassadorial appointments to pressure Clinton to reorganize the State Department.

The number of presidential appointees has multiplied--including judges, there are more than 4,000, five times as many as in Kennedy's time--making it difficult for the Senate to find time to consider everyone.
All Cabinet-level appointees are now fair game for a confirmation challenge.
